sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Cerebral blood flow radionuclide study: 70-kg patient: 370 to 1110 megabecquerels (10 to 30 millicuries) INHALED in 3 L of air
  • Imaging of lung: 70-kg patient: 74 to 1110 megabecquerels (2 to 30 millicuries) INHALED in 3 L of air

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and efficacy not established in pediatric patients

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono: elderly: use caution with dose selection, starting with the low end of the dosing range

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Cerebral blood flow radionuclide study
  • Imaging of lung

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: specific contraindications have not been determined

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• latex sensitivity; vial stopper contains dry natural rubber latex
  • potential loss of radioactivity due to adherence of the gas to plastics and rubber; may render study non-diagnostic; product should not be allowed to stand in tubing or respirator containers
  • radiopharmaceutical; handle with care and use safety measures to reduce radiation exposure to personnel and patient

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Xenon Xe 133 gas is a mixture of xenon gas (5%) and carbon dioxide (95%) and as a inhaled diagnostic agent it readily diffuses through the alveolar wall into the pulmonary venous circulation and readily exchanges between blood and tissue, allowing evaluation of pulmonary function and imaging of the lungs as well as assessment of cerebral blood flow. Xenon Xe 133 gas is chemically and physiologically related to elemental xenon, which has anesthetic properties at high doses. At doses used for diagnostic imaging, however, xenon Xe 133 is physiologically inactive.

4.title: Elimination Half Life
4.mono: Cerebral vasculature: 5 minutes; pulmonary vasculature: 2 minutes

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Inhalation
  • handle with care and employ appropriate safety measures to minimize radiation exposure to patients and clinical personnel
  • do not allow to stand in rubber tubing or respiratory containers
  • measure patient dose by a suitable radioactivity calibration system immediately before administration
  • administer by inhalation from closed (ie, leakproof) respiratory systems or spirometers
  • exhaled xenon Xe 133 gas should be controlled in compliance with appropriate governmental regulations

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono: no specific monitoring has been determined
